passages.text: First Take: 1H25 results fall short; three reasons for caution following a strong YTD rally

Our First Take: China Taiping has been a YTD outperformer (57% vs. HSI: 25%), as the market has viewed this stock as a strong beta play. However, the positive stock market rally has yet to translate into favorable earnings growth. We believe the market may initially react unfavorably to the outcome. We highlight three key disappointments: (1) earnings miss: a substantial decline in unrealized gains from fair value through profit or loss (FVPL) in the bond portfolio led the company to report 1H25 net profit of HK\(6.8B, for 12%\) \text{oya growth, notably below JPME of HK\$7.2B; (2) absence of an interim dividend: shareholder return initiatives are a focal point in the sector, and major listed China SOEs have proposed 1H25 interim dividends similar to previous years' - the company's consecutive two- year omission of an interim dividend despite a sufficient capital base is unlikely to be perceived positively by the market; and (3) relative valuation: the stock currently trades at a 7x FY26E P/E with only a 2% yield vs. \~4- 6% at major H- listed peers. We believe China Re and Ping An- H are more compelling alternatives for investors seeking dividend plays. Stay UW.

Key PositivesNew business value. The 1H25 NBV print was solid, at HK\(6.7B, indicating 23%\) \text{oya growth on a like- for- like basis. Following strong new life sales in participating policies (}\( \sim 87\% \) out of regular FYP) and ongoing commission fee cuts, the product margin books in both the agency and bancassurance channels see enduring improvement. That said, overall NBV margin rose to 21.6% in 1H25 from 18.5% in 1H24. Solvency capital. Taiping Life/Taiping P&C/Taiping Pension managed their core solvency ratios at 194%/179%/161% by end- Jun- 25, well above the regulatory minimum requirement of 50%.

Key Negatives/Question MarksFalling investment gain. The unrealized gain in the bond portfolio under the classification of FVPL saw a substantial decline, from 1H24's profit of HK\(5.8B to a\) \text{TH25 loss of HK\$2.1B, due to the adverse impact of domestic market interest rate movements, undermining overall investment performance. Interim dividend agenda. Major China SOE insurers have proposed interim dividend distribution for two consecutive years. We believe interim dividend proposals are likely to be the new norm in the insurance sector, especially considering rising investor interest in shareholder return agendas. Hence, as the company has demonstrated solid capital adequacy, a key consideration in deciding interim dividends and, more importantly, the visibility of interim dividend moving forward, might be crucial on tomorrow's result call.
We expect near- term upward revisions, as 1H25 net profit of HK\(6.8B represents 72% of FY25E consensus earnings.
Underweight0966. HK, 966 HKPrice: HK\(18.30 28 Aug 2025Price Target: HK\)8.20PT End Date: 31 Dec 2025
We expect a negative share price reaction following this interim result.
Table 1: China Taiping: Earnings table

Source: China Taiping 1H25 interim report.
Table 2: China Taiping: Asset allocation trend
Source: China Taiping's Annual Reports for FY20-24 and interim report for 1H25, J.P. Morgan calculations.

China Taiping is the longest- operating SOE insurer, with a strong track record of serving national needs. Based on total gross written premiums, the company's life/non- life segment, Taiping Life/Taiping P&C, held China market shares of \(4.2\% /1.8\%\) in 2024. We highlight the stronger- than- peers' NBV growth over 2024- 27E (i.e., NBV CAGR of \(12\%\) ) over 4 years' \(4 - 13\%\) ) on our estimates), underpinned by headcount stabilization, enhanced productivity and a balanced distribution channel contribution. However, high earnings dependence on the life segment might anchor the company's value as a pure life player. Thus, we believe the downside risk outweighs upside risk. Underweight.

Our Dec- 25 PT of HK\$8.20 is derived from a sum- of- the- parts (SOTP) valuation methodology. We assign 4x FY25E P/E to the life business, a 2x P/E to the non- life business and reinsurance business, and a 1x P/E to Others. Our PT implies a 4x FY25E P/E at the consolidated level, close to the historical trough, considering that the China insurance sector has re- rated over the past few years (historical average/minimum of 8x/3x).

J.P. Morgan ratings or designations: OW = Overweight, N= Neutral, UW = Underweight, NR = Not Rated

J.P. Morgan uses the following rating system: Overweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will outperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); Neutral (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will perform in line with the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); and Underweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe. NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating and, if applicable, the price target, for this stock because of either a lack of a sufficient fundamental basis or for legal, regulatory or policy reasons. The previous rating and, if applicable, the price target, no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. In Americas equity research, some stocks under coverage have a rating but no price target; in these cases, we expect the stock will outperform/perform in line/underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe over the next six to 12 months. In our Asia (ex-Australia and ex-India) and U.K. small- and mid- cap Equity Research, each stock's expected total return is compared to the expected total return of a benchmark country market index, not to those Research Analysts' coverage universe. If it does not appear in the Important Disclaimer section of this report, the certifying Research Analyst's coverage universe can be found on J.P.
